VLIB_subtractBackgroundS32

Detailed Description


Functions

int32_t VLIB_subtractBackgroundS32 (uint32_t *restrict mask32packed, const uint8_t *restrict newLuma, const int32_t *restrict runningMean, const int32_t *restrict runningVar, const int32_t thresholdGlobal, const int32_t thresholdFactor, const uint32_t PixelCount)

Function Documentation

int32_t VLIB_subtractBackgroundS32 ( uint32_t *restrict  mask32packed,
const uint8_t *restrict  newLuma,
const int32_t *restrict  runningMean,
const int32_t *restrict  runningVar,
const int32_t  thresholdGlobal,
const int32_t  thresholdFactor,
const uint32_t  PixelCount 
)

Description:
The function VLIB_subtractBackgroundS32() implements a statistical background segmentation algorithm. For each pixel, the running mean and variance statistics are available. Given a novel luma observation, we test whether its squared distance from the mean is larger than a multiplicative factor of its variance. For a pixel to pass the test, its distance should also be greater than a predefined global threshold, designed to capture inherent camera noise. When these conditions are satisfied, the observation is deemed to stem from a foreground object (and not from the modeled background), and the corresponding mask pixel value is set to 1.
Parameters:
[out] mask32packed Binary mask to be determined (32-bit packed)
[in] newLuma Most recent Luma data (UQ8.0)
[in] runningMean Exponentially weighted running mean buffer (SQ8.23)
[in] runningVar Exponentially weighted running variance buffer (SQ16.15)
[in] thresholdGlobal Global threshold value (SQ16.15)
[in] thresholdFactor Multiplicative factor for threshold (SQ4.27)
[in] PixelCount Number of pixels to process (UQ32.0)
Assumptions:
  • I/O buffers are assumed to be double-word aligned and not aliased.
  • The PixelCount must be a multiple of 32.
Implementation Notes:
  • This code is fully interruptible
  • This code is compatible with C6XXX fixed-point processors
Benchmarks:
See VLIB_Test_Report.html for cycle and memory information.
